problemType.problemTypeName: FindSecBugs: Cipher with no integrity
FindSecBugs: DES is insecure
FindSecBugs: ECB mode is insecure
FindSecBugs: Hard coded password
Hard-Coded Credentials: Password in Java Variables
problemType.description:
Checks for password variables to which constant strings are assigned.
See CWE number 259 for details.

problemType.problemTypeName: SpotBugs: Field should be both final and package protected
problemType.description: A mutable static field could be changed by malicious code or by accident from another package. The field could be made package protected and/or made final to avoid this vulnerability.

problemType.problemTypeName: SpotBugs: Field should be package protected
problemType.description: A mutable static field could be changed by malicious code or by accident. The field could be made package protected to avoid this vulnerability.

problemType.problemTypeName: SpotBugs: Field isn't final but should be
problemType.description: This static field public but not final, and could be changed by malicious code or by accident from another package. The field could be made final to avoid this vulnerability.

problemType.problemTypeName: SpotBugs: Read of unwritten field
problemType.description: The program is dereferencing a field that does not seem to ever have a non-null value written to it. Unless the field is initialized via some mechanism not seen by the analysis, dereferencing this value will generate a null pointer exception.

problemType.problemTypeName: FindSecBugs: Cipher is susceptible to Padding Oracle
FindSecBugs: Predictable pseudorandom number generator
FindSecBugs: Static IV
Cryptography: Cryptographic Algorithms Used in Project
problemType.description:
Searches in project code for all methods which set, select or determine a cryptographic algorithm. The goal is to find out which cryptographic algorithms are applied in the code.
See CWE number 327 for details.

problemType.problemTypeName: Cryptography: Cryptographic Algorithms w/o Specified Crypto-Provider
problemType.description:
Searches in project code for all methods which set, select or determine a cryptographic algorithm and do not specify a crypto-provider for it, although an alternative method with a parameter for the provider is available. Not specifx the crypto-provider makes it uncertain which crypto-provider the server will use - it might be an unsafe one.
See CWE number 325 for details.

problemType.problemTypeName: Usage: PrintStackTrace
problemType.description:
Depending on the system configuration, using java.lang.Throwable.printStackTrace can expose an exception to a remote user. In some cases the error message tells the attacker precisely what sort of an attack the system will be vulnerable to.
See CWE number 497 for details.
problemType.howToFix: Use an appropriately configured logging mechanism and log the exception directly into a log file that is not viewable by an end user.

problemType.problemTypeName: Usage: java.util.Random
problemType.description:
Instances of class 'java.util.Random' are not cryptographically secure. Consider instead using class 'java.security.SecureRandom' to get a cryptographically secure pseudo-random number generator for security-sensitive applications.
See CWE number 330 for details. Additional CWEs are: 332, 338.

problemType.problemTypeName: FindSecBugs: HostnameVerifier that accept any signed certificates
FindSecBugs: MD2, MD4 and MD5 are weak hash functions
FindSecBugs: SHA-1 is a weak hash function
FindSecBugs: TrustManager that accept any certificates
Hard-Coded Credentials: Cryptographic Key as Method Parameter
problemType.description:
This security problem represents an access to some protected system component using hard-coded cryptographic keys.
Do not additionally assign a taint source kind to this problem type. It would be superfluous in this scenario and has no effect.
See CWE number 321 for details.
problemType.howToFix: Remove cryptographic key from the code.

problemType.problemTypeName: Cryptography: AES Encryption
problemType.description:
AES problems concerning encryption.
AES is a recommended algorithm for symmetric encryption and decryption. Problems in AES encryption include wrong construction of a new encryption key object, wrong construction of an encryption cipher object, and wrong use of an encryption cipher in a cipher output stream.
See CWE number 310 for details. Additional CWEs are: 329.
problemType.howToFix: Correct the sequence of method invocations so that they match the AES encryption protocols.

problemType.problemTypeName: Cryptography: Cryptographic Hashing
problemType.description:
Problems concerning wrong use of cryptographic hashing.
Cryptographic hashes (aka message digests) are hashes that fulfill some special criteria. This problem type checks the proper use of the message digest API when initializing and using a digest object.
See CWE number 328 for details.
problemType.howToFix: Correct the sequence of method invocations so that they match the cryptographic hashing protocols.

problemType.problemTypeName: Cryptography: Check that only allowed crypto algorithms are used
problemType.description:
Uses of non-allowed crypto algorithms.
See CWE number 327 for details. Additional CWEs are: 780.
problemType.howToFix: Use one of the allowed crypto algorithms instead.

problemType.problemTypeName: Cryptography: Check that only allowed hash algorithms are used
problemType.description:
Uses of non-allowed hash algorithms.
See CWE number 328 for details.
problemType.howToFix: Use one of the allowed hash algorithms instead.

problemType.problemTypeName: Cryptography: Password-Based Encryption
problemType.description:
Problems concerning wrong use of password-based encryption.
Password-based encryption constructs cryptographic keys from passwords. A hash function, an iteration count and a salt are needed here. This problem type checks for correct generation of key specs and keys, algorithm parameter specs and algorithm parameters, and ciphers.
See CWE number 310 for details. Additional CWEs are: 759, 760, 916.
problemType.howToFix: Correct the sequence of method invocations so that they match the password-based encryption protocols.

problemType.problemTypeName: Cryptography: Basic Protocol Violations for RSA Encryption and Decryption
problemType.description:
RSA problems concerning both encryption and decryption.
RSA is a recommended algorithm for asymmetric encryption and decryption. Problems in RSA encryption and decryption include wrong construction and use of a an RSA key generation parameter spec of wrong key pair generation.
See CWE number 310 for details.
problemType.howToFix: Correct the sequence of method invocations so that they match the RSA protocols that are used both in encryption and decryption.

problemType.problemTypeName: Cryptography: Construction of Secure Random Number Generator
problemType.description:
Problems concerning secure random number generator construction.
Secure random number generator construction might be compromised, e.g., by using a non-securely constructed seed.
See CWE number 310 for details. Additional CWEs are: 335, 337, 338.
problemType.howToFix: Correct the sequence of method invocations so that they match the secure random number construction protocols.

problemType.problemTypeName: Resource Leak: IO Stream Resource Leak
problemType.description:
This problem type searches for IO streams in the code that are opened but never closed. This has a negative impact on performance and availability. Such unreleased resources can be classified as a security risk because they enable a denial-of-service attack.
In this analysis certain resources as e.g. HttpServletResponse.getOutputStream() are not supposed to be closed by the servlet. Instead the servlet container must do that in this example.
Xanitizer reports all code paths where the dataflow starts from a created resource instance and is leaving the validity scope of that resource without having it closed. This is the case when the dataflow reaches a point (marked as a taint sink) in the code after that no further access to the resource instance occurs.
This resource leak search does not work if the resource object is stored in non-local variables.
See CWE number 404 for details. Additional CWEs are: 772.
problemType.howToFix: Close the stream (preferably in a finally block).

problemType.problemTypeName: Resource Leak: Socket Resource Leak
problemType.description:
This problem type reports paths where a socket is opened but never closed. Such unreleased resources can be classified as a security risk because they enable a denial-of-service attack.
Xanitizer reports all code paths where the dataflow starts from a created resource instance and is leaving the validity scope of that resource without having it closed. This is the case when the dataflow reaches a point (marked as a taint sink) in the code after that no further access to the resource instance occurs.
This resource leak search does not work if the resource object is stored in non-local variables.
See CWE number 404 for details. Additional CWEs are: 772.
problemType.howToFix: Close the socket (preferably in a finally block).

problemType.problemTypeName: SSL/TLS Validation: Suspicious Implementation
problemType.description:
Searches for project-specific implementations for SSL/TLS validation. Quite often such home-grown implementations are imperfect. Verify whether project-specific implementations perform all necessary validation steps:
* Is the certificate signed by a "trusted" CA (see CWE-296)?
* Is the host name matching the certificateâ€˜s CN (see CWE-297)?
* Is the certificate expired (see CWE-298)?
* Has the certificate been revoked (see CWE-299, CWE-370)?
If not, check where these project-specific implementations are used ? Just in test code or also in production code ?
See CWE number 295 for details.
